Creation and calibration method of acoustical models for historic virtual reality auralizations
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Spatial Sound
  • Published: 09 September 2015

Creation and calibration method of acoustical models for historic virtual reality auralizations

  • Barteld N. J. Postma1 &
  • Brian F. G. Katz1 

Virtual Reality volume 19, pages161–180(2015)Cite this article

  • 766 Accesses

  • 15 Citations

  • 6 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Virtual reality provides the possibility for interactive visits to historic buildings and sites. The majority of current virtual reconstructions have focused on creating realistic virtual environments, by concentrating on the visual component. However, by incorporating more authentic acoustical properties into visual models, a more realistic rendering of the studied venue is achieved. In historic auralizations, calibration of the studied building’s room acoustic simulation model is often necessary to come to a realistic representation of its acoustical environment. This paper presents a methodical calibration procedure for geometrical acoustics models using room acoustics prediction programs based on geometrical acoustics to create realistic virtual audio realities, or auralizations. To develop this procedure, a small unfinished amphitheater was first chosen due to its general simplicity and considerable level of reverberation. A geometrical acoustics model was calibrated according to the results of acoustical measurements. Measures employed during the calibration of this model were analyzed to come to a methodical calibration procedure. The developed procedure was then applied to a more complex building, the abbey church Saint-Germain-des-Prés. A possible application of the presented procedure is to enable interactive acoustical visits of former configurations of buildings. A test case study was carried out for a typical seventeenth-century configuration of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

Introduction

Ideally, a virtual reality-based heritage experience allows visitors to feel they are present at significant places and times in the past and use a variety of senses to experience what it would have felt like to be there. Virtual reality recreations have emphasized the sensory experience of sight and have gained in importance for historical research over recent decades (Angelini and Milan 2010). For example, the Virtual New Amsterdam Prototype project presented a recreation of New York City (a.k.a. New Amsterdam) as it looked during the seventeenth century, offering a tool via Google Earth that enabled visitors to enter a 3D environment of the historic city (Environmental Simulation Center 2014). A visualization of the architectural history of Paris since Roman times was created with similar techniques (Busson and Ferrand 2012; Dassault Systems 2015). These models are available for online visits. Comparable visualizations of various cities in the Netherlands during the seventeenth century have also been created (Tuytel 2013, 2014). While some of these works can only be viewed on traditional computer screens, several allow for immersive renderings using the Oculus Rift HMD.Footnote 1 Copper and Tanan (2015) recently presented such a virtual reconstruction of an elaborate labyrinth of the seventeenth- and eighteenth-century gardens of the Chateau de Versailles.

Virtual reality recreations have predominantly emphasized visual aspects. In response, McDermott and Chu (2007) have argued that users should be able to accurately perceive the acoustical nature of the environment as well. The term auralization was first introduced by Kleiner et al. (1993) as an acoustical analogy to visualization, to describe rendering audible virtual sound fields. Auralization is a technique based on capturing or modeling impulse responses of environments and convolving them with anechoic audio: music, speech, or other suitable signals.

Analogous to visualizations, auralizations can be used to enable virtual reality visits to historical sites and buildings. For example, Pedrero and Daz-Chyla (2014) virtually restored a group of Spanish pre-Romanesque churches. The simulated room impulse responses (RIR) were convolved with recordings of Mozarabic Chants. Weitze et al. (2001) studied historic mosques and byzantine churches in Istanbul. For this study, a live performance recording was compared with a simulated RIR convolved with anechoic recordings. Garcia et al. (2014) studied the change in acoustical conditions for performances of the “Misteri d’Elx” in the Basilica “Santa Maria de Elche.” Models of the Basilica were simulated and calibrated based on in-situ measurements of material absorption coefficients. Finally, a study of the Fogg Art Museum, in which Wallace C. Sabine performed his first experiments on reverberation time in 1898, produced a calibrated historical model (Katz and Wetherill 2005).

In order to achieve realistic auralizations, it is important to have a well-calibrated geometrical acoustics (GA) model. In cases where the building still exists, physical measurements are possible, allowing comparisons between the simulated and measured acoustic response. Vorländer (2010) proposes that a simulation is well calibrated when the difference between simulation and measurement is less than the perceivable difference per considered objective acoustical parameter. Alternatively, a direct means of validating the simulation could be the use of subjective listening tests where simulated auralizations are compared to actual recordings (Lokki and Järveläinen 2001). Comparisons of acoustic signals are also possible, such as those by Katz and Wetherill (2005), who compared measured and simulated RIR envelopes. Building upon these previous studies, this study proposes a methodical approach to obtain calibrated auralizations using measured acoustic responses in real conditions.

Terms

Due to the interdisciplinary nature of multimodal virtual reality research, and the range of terms used for similar concepts throughout the literature, a brief list of pertinent terms frequently used in the following manuscript is provided here for clarity.

  • Geometrical model The geometrical model consisting solely of an ensemble of defined surfaces. The geometry of a room is a relatively straightforward concept, with the main variable being the complexity of the model.

  • Geometrical acoustics (GA) model The model comprising the geometrical model with the inclusion of acoustic material properties assigned to each surfaces. Surface material properties such as absorption coefficients are applied in GA algorithms by diminishing the energy of incident rays after a reflection from a surface by the absorption coefficient.

  • Geometrical acoustics (GA) software The prediction software which implements various GA algorithms used to carry out the numerical simulations based on the GA model as input. Throughout this study, TUCT v1.1a, CATT-Acoustic v.9.0.c, was employed. This software allows for various physical feature definitions in the GA model consisting of the geometry, sound absorption, and scattering. These properties can be considered analogous to the geometry, RGB color values, and diffusion material properties in visualization software.

  • Reverberance Refers to the quality of a sound that persists in a room after a played tone is abruptly stopped (Beranek 1996). It can be quantified in simple rooms by the acoustic parameters T30, T20, and EDT, which vary as a function of frequency. T30 is the reverberation time (the time for a sound to decay by 60 dB) extrapolated from the decay between \(-5\) and \(-35\) dB. T20 is similarly obtained from the level decay between \(-5\) and \(-25\) dB. EDT is the early decay time, obtained as T30 but extrapolated from the decay between 0 and \(-10\) dB. EDT is related to perceived running reverberance, while T30 and T20 are associated with the perceived late reverberant decay.

  • Clarity The degree to which discrete sounds stand apart from each other (Beranek 1996), relating to perceived definition and speech intelligibility. These subjective parameters correlate with the acoustic parameters C50 and C80 which are logarithmic ratios between early and late arriving energy, which vary as a function of frequency, calculated, respectively, for a time division of 50 (for speech) and 80 ms (for music).

  • Just noticeable difference (JND) The smallest perceivable difference for an objective parameter. The ISO 3382-1 standard on room acoustic measurements states that the generally accepted JND for reverberation parameters is 5 % and for clarity-related parameters is 1 dB. While some variations in these JND values may exist depending on specific conditions, we propose to use these baseline values as a limiting metric for perceptual relevance as there is no evidence that other proposed JNDs would offer a better estimation (Seraphim 1958; Cox et al. 1993; Bradley et al. 1999; Ahearn et al. 2008).

General procedure

The general calibration procedure is proposed here. While some details of the GA model construction may be specific to the selected software package, the general approach proposed should be applicable to any GA software that produces RIRs suitable for auralizations.

  1. 1.

    RIR measurements are carried out in the studied venue. The results of these measurements are used as a reference for the calibration.

  2. 2.

    The geometrical model is created and remains unchanged during the remainder of the calibration.

  3. 3.

    Preliminary acoustical properties are assigned to the geometrical model’s surfaces, resulting in the GA model. Assigning coefficients for specific materials includes the need to take into account, in addition to the actual material:

    • The construction/installation variances of a given material relative to published measured data.

    • The adaptation of published normal incidence data to random incidence coefficients as required in GA software.

    • The assumptions on defining representative coefficients for geometrical model surfaces representing various materials.

    Local geometry variations are represented by the scattering coefficient which is required for the definition of simpler geometrical surfaces and any associated acoustical texture. The direct impact of this variable on the simulation results is less obvious and can vary as a function of ‘mixing’ properties of the specific geometry and absorption distribution. In addition, variations exist due to the various means by which different GA algorithms implement scattering models. Therefore, an initial step in the applied calibration method is directed toward gauging the sensitivity of simulation results due to scattering coefficients for the given GA model and GA software’s algorithms.

  4. 4.

    Attention is given to the run-to-run variation in the simulations and the influence of some of the GA model’s parameters. There have been numerous studies on the variability and repeatability of acoustical RIR measurements (James 2003, 2004) and RIR measurement analysis (Katz 2004). Similarly, stochastic implementation of the Lambert function for scattering in GA software leads to run-to-run variations in the applied algorithm (Dalenbäck 2010). Because of these stochastic variations, it is important to ascertain the degree of variance expected in the results for repeated “virtual measurements” in a given configuration. These variations can then be taken into account when comparing results and the degree of accordance achievable when attempting to obtain a calibrated model. Therefore, the second step in the applied calibration method is devoted to ascertaining the run-to-run variation.

  5. 5.

    Acoustical surface properties are modified, taking into account the determined sensitivity, in order to arrive at global mean differences (for the same source and receiver configurations) between measurement and simulated results for reverberation and clarity parameters of less than 1 JND.

  6. 6.

    Acoustical properties of local key surfaces are adjusted to minimize the standard deviation (SD) of the differences between measured and simulated results for reverberance and clarity parameters.

This procedure relies on several assumptions:

  • The selected acoustic parameters for reverberation and clarity are sufficient metrics for the calibration procedure.

  • Calibration according to a collection of objective acoustical parameters within 1 JND results in a valid simulation.

  • Calibration of a GA model for a sufficient ensemble of discrete points (source and receiver positions) provides sufficient confidence in the quality of the simulated RIR at other positions.

In addition to these assumptions, it should be noted that the procedure for generating an audible RIR from the numerical simulation results is not a neutral process. Different GA software performs this procedure differently. Furthermore, due to previously reported variations in room acoustic impulse response analysis algorithm implementations (Katz 2004), it is important to use a single analysis tool for estimating the acoustic parameters when comparing results from measured and simulated RIRs.

In Sects. 4, 5, and 6, this calibration procedure is first developed for a small unfinished 200-seat lecture hall (in French called the amphitheater) which had a rather simple geometry and material selection. Secondly, the procedure was applied to a more complex configuration, the abbey church of Saint-Germain-des-Prés, Paris. Subsequently, Sect. 7 applies the calibrated Saint-Germain-des-Prés GA model to study a typical seventeenth-century configuration as a test case for the virtual acoustical simulation process.

Construction of the geometrical acoustics models

A primary consideration in the construction of a geometrical acoustics model is the level of detail. A model with too fine detail will result in high computation costs and at the same time will be inaccurate. Surface elements that are very small with respect to acoustic wavelength are poorly considered by GA algorithms, with small elements either reflecting more energy than their area permits or conversely being ignored as their surface area is too small. The result being that an overly detailed model will be more suited to only high-frequency calculations. As such, one should avoid overly detailed models, and rather rely on somewhat larger surfaces and defined scattering properties to account for surface textures (Vorländer 2008).

To create the GA model from the geometrical model, it is necessary to define the acoustic properties of each surface element. The sound absorption coefficient describes the fraction of sound that is absorbed at each reflection from a given surface, with this value being defined as a function of frequency. Numerous sources of data can be found for material properties (e.g., Beranek 1986, 1996; Vorländer 2008). Coefficients in these databases correspond typically to random sound incidence conditions, as they were obtained from measurements in reverberation chambers and are often employed in reverberation time calculations according to the Sabine equation, or its derivatives. Other sources may provide normal incidence absorption condition coefficients, which are typically used in boundary element or finite element numerical simulations with the coefficient being modeled for nonnormal incidence (Katz 2000a, b, 2001).

Somewhat analogous to texture mapping and bump mapping in graphics, GA algorithms may incorporate diffraction- or scattering-type effects. These effects can be associated with two types of phenomena, those related to surface irregularities and those caused by the limited size of the surface as well as edge diffraction (Zeng et al. 2006). Both phenomena are a function of wavelength. Surface scattering can be estimated, based on wavelength of the incident sound compared to the surface depth variation. Scattering coefficients can also be measured or simulated using detailed numerical acoustical simulations, although few data sets are publicly available (ISO 17497 2007; Cox and D’Antonio 2009; Vorländer 2008). Algorithms for edge diffusion are typically based on the size of the object (Lokki et al. 2002; Pulkki and Lokki 2003). Inclusion of higher-order diffraction effects and especially true edge diffraction can significantly increase computational costs.

The frequency-dependent scattering coefficient (\({\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}\)) can be estimated as a function of a given characteristic depth (\({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\)) representative of the surface’s depth variations or roughness. The estimation algorithm in Eq. (1) is included in CATT-Acoustic by the estimate function, though specific values can also be directly assigned as a function of frequency.

$${\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}(f)\Bigg |_{\ge 0.10}^{\le 0.99} = {0.5 {\sqrt{{\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\over \lambda }}}$$
(1)

where \(\lambda\) is the wavelength. Values are clipped to the range (\(0.10\le {\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}\le 0.99\)). This clipping implies that values of \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}} \le 0.004\) m result in a constant \({\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}=0.1\), or 10 % in the 4-kHz band, at which point scattering begins to increase. Values of \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}} \ge 0.11\) m are required to affect \({\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}\) in the lowest 125-Hz band. This method of defining \({\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}\) was selected as it provides a more intuitive and physically relevant control parameter and reduces the possibility of creating unrealistic frequency variations in scattering properties for general materials.

The amphitheater and Saint-Germain-des-Prés’s geometrical acoustics models were created according to the aforementioned guidelines. Absorption coefficients were first selected from publicly available databases. In order to avoid the need to define the scattering coefficient for every surface as a function of frequency, the geometrical approximation estimate was generally used as a starting point.

Unfinished amphitheater

The geometry of the amphitheater was determined by on-site measurements. Figure 1 shows the interior of the room. Figure 2 depicts the geometrical model. The plan of the room is rectangular (12 m \(\times\) 14.9 m) with the exception of an intruding smaller rectangle (2.5 m \(\times\) 1.9 m) to the right of the entrance (see door in Fig. 1).

The materials and finishes of the amphitheater were determined by visual inspection. The floor is made of concrete. The wall, in which the entrance door is positioned, is unpainted plaster board (see Fig. 1). The remaining walls are concrete for the lower part with profiled aluminum panels above. The ceiling is profiled aluminum panels. In front of these panels, metal construction elements are exposed. The profiled aluminum panels of the walls have a relief of 8 mm and those in the ceiling of 80 mm. As these undulating panels diffuse sound only along one dimension, they were modeled using the 1D scattering option, L1, in CATT-Acoustic, which includes the direction of scattering for the surface.

Saint-Germain-des-Prés

The more complex geometry of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés was determined from both a 3D laser scan point cloud and architectural plans and sections. The abbey church (see Figs. 3, 4) is approximately 78 m long, 21 m wide, and 18 m high.

The surface materials were determined by visual inspection. The floor and pulpit are marble. Reed chairs are positioned in the center part of the nave and to the left and right of the high altar. The columns, walls, and ceiling are generally painted plaster, except in the sanctuary’s side aisles where these are exposed limestone. Large paintings hang in the left-side aisles, except in the fourth nave where a large statue is present.

Statues were modeled by simple bounding boxes with high scattering. Plaster was modeled acoustically flat, \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of 1 mm, and the limestone surfaces were modeled with \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of 10 mm to account for variations in texture and ornamentation. The \({\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}\) of the pews and reed chairs were defined following guidelines in the CATT-Acoustic manual which recommends these to be modeled with \({\mathrm{scatt}}_{\mathrm{coef}}\) of 30–80 %, rising 10 % per octave band (Dalenbäck 2011, p. 85).

Measurements

This section describes the measurements carried out in order to serve as a point of reference for the calibration of the geometrical acoustics models.

  • Signal The excitation signal was based on the Swept Sine method. The sweep frequency rose exponentially over 10 s from 20 to 20 kHz. This method produces a distortion-free linear response, eliminating high-order harmonic distortion effects, thereby offering clear improvements over other methods (Rébillat et al. 2010; Farina 2000). This method is capable of obtaining higher signal-to-noise-ratios (SNR) for the same signal power and is more robust against external noise. The sweep was played and recorded with a sample rate of 44.1 kHz using DAW software (Reaper) and sound card (RME, Fireface 800). Subsequent deconvolution and postprocessing steps were carried out in MATLABFootnote 2 to obtain the RIRs. RIRs were analyzed using LIMSI’s in-house MATLAB impulse response analysis (IRA) toolkit in accordance with ISO 3382-1 (2009).

  • Sound source The audio output was sent to an amplifier (SAMSOM, model Servo 120a) and sequentially to two miniature dodecahedral sound sources (Dr-Three, model 3D-032).

  • Microphones Four omnidirectional microphones (DPA, model 4006) were employed. For Saint-Germain-des-Prés, a B-format microphone (Core Audio, model TetraMic) and an artificial head (Neuman, model KU 80, equipped with DPA, model 4060) were additionally used, though their results are not presented here.

  • Measurement protocol Figure 5 shows the measurement plans with source and receiver positions for the two rooms. Because the amphitheater floor consists of two levels connected by a ramp, one source position per level was measured with a distribution of 12 microphone positions over the auditorium, eight on the lower level and four on the upper. Source positions in the Saint-Germain-des-Prés were chosen in accordance with ISO 3382-1 (2009), representing typical usage [pulpit (S1) and altar (S2)]. Thirty microphone positions, representing normal attendee positions, were chosen from the second to fifth bay of the nave (1–2, 4–7, 9–12, 14–17, 19–20), the high altar (21–22, 24–25), and the sanctuary (26–27, 29–30). The B-format microphone and artificial head were located at six center-line positions (3, 8, 13, 18, 23, 28).

Calibration of the simulation model

As with any simulation for scientific purposes, it is necessary to calibrate models. For a visual model, this could be in reference to objective analysis methods such as colorimetry and image correlation analysis. In the context of virtual acoustic simulations, the current study employs measured acoustic parameters, as described in the Sect. 2. In this section, the proposed general calibration procedure is detailed, in accordance with the selected GA software, and demonstrated for the amphitheater. It is then applied to the more complex Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

Various GA software programs can directly provide room acoustic parameter values in addition to RIRs suitable for auralization. However, following the discussion in Sect. 3, the analysis of the simulated RIR audio files to obtain the acoustic parameters was carried out using the same software that was used for the measured RIRs as noted in Sect. 5. In order to avoid issues regarding automatic noise detection algorithms when applied to the ideal background noise-free simulated RIRs, a low level white Gaussian noise (\(-65\) dB) was added to the simulated RIRs prior to acoustic parameter analysis. The remainder of this section describes the calibration procedure conducted in the considered rooms.

Calibration method specifics

While the general calibration method presented in Sect. 3 should be applicable to all GA software that produces RIRs for auralizations, the six-step method detailed in the following section is presented in the context of the selected GA software, CATT-Acoustic.

  1. 1.

    Identification of relevant absorption coefficients from various databases of materials. The variation among data for comparable materials aides in defining a reasonable range of values which can be used in the calibration process (Martellota and Morales 2014).

  2. 2.

    Running 10 repetitions of the initial simulation configuration, analysis of the average of the SD calculated per position for each acoustic parameter quantifies the run-to-run variation for the given GA model.Footnote 3

  3. 3.

    The sensitivity of the GA model to the scattering coefficient is investigated. Simulations are run of the initial GA model followed by simulations with all scattering coefficients set to 0 % and then to 99 %, with all absorption coefficients unchanged.

  4. 4.

    Absorption coefficients are adjusted to bring the reverberation parameters within 1 JND of the measured value. The first materials to be adjusted are those with the largest surface areas, since small variations lead to considerable effects.Footnote 4

  5. 5.

    Based on the results of step 3, the scattering coefficients are adjusted to calibrate the average clarity parameters to within 1 JND of the measured values.

  6. 6.

    Having calibrated the average parameter values, the final step refines the calibration by minimizing the SD of the differences between simulated and measured parameters, considering all source-receiver positions. This step is accomplished by examining the results for each position and making local adjustments to predominant surface properties relative to source and receiver positions while assuring the previous calibration steps’ results concerning mean values are not altered.

The following sections present an overview of the calibration steps for the two considered models.

Amphitheater

The proposed calibration procedure was applied to the amphitheater.Footnote 5 After completing the material search of step 1, 10 simulation repetitions were run to determine the variance in results for the GA model, according to step 2. The upper graphs in Fig. 6 show that the SD of T20 exceeds 1 JND in the 125-Hz octave band, and the SD of C50 exceeds the JND of 1 dB in the 125 and 250 Hz octave bands. As such, the degree of tolerance for T20 and C50 in calibrating the GA model to the measured data should realistically be extended beyond 1 JND in these octave bands. To reduce the effect of run-to-run variance, all subsequent results are the average of 5 simulation repetitions.

Following step 3, simulations were run with all scattering set to 0 % and subsequently all scattering set to 99 %. The lower graphs in Fig. 6 indicate that T20 is stable when the scattering is varied, but C50 increases when the scattering is reduced, and vice versa. This information is employed during the calibration procedure. The details of steps 4–6 are presented in detail in “Appendix 1”.

With the calibration concluded, the initial values are compared to those of the calibrated GA model. Figure 7 shows T20, EDT, C50, and C80 of the initial and final GA model iterations and the measurement. In the initial iteration, both T20 and EDT were overestimated by more than 1 JND in the 125-Hz octave band and underestimated by more than 1 JND in the 250-, 2000-, and 4000-Hz octave bands. In the final iteration, these were brought within 1 JND of the measured values. C50 and C80 were initially considerably overestimated in the 250- and 4000-Hz octave bands and these were better estimated in the final calibrated version of the GA model. The final acoustic parameter results are within the average run-to-run variation, established in step 2, compared to the measurements.

The main changes in the surface properties of the GA model were the adjustment of the aluminum and objects absorption coefficients as well as the adjustments of the scattering coefficients of the concrete, aluminum, and plaster panels. For an extensive discussion on the modifications regarding material properties, see “Appendix 1”.

Saint-Germain-des-Prés

Having established the proposed calibration protocol in Sect. 6.2, the procedure was then applied to a more complex case, the Saint-Germain-des-Prés.Footnote 6

After the material search in step 1, the 10 simulation repetitions were carried out according to step 2. Figure 8 shows that the mean SD of T20 across all octave bands was less than 1 JND. However, the mean C50 across all octave bands is near to or greater than 1 JND. To reduce the effect of run-to-run variance, all subsequent results are the average of five simulation repetitions.

Following step 3, simulations were run of the initial iteration with all scattering coefficients set to 0 and 99 %. The lower graphs in Fig. 8 indicate that T20 is stable with respect to scattering coefficient modifications, as is C50 in the 125-Hz octave band. In the 250-Hz octave band, C50 increases when the scattering is reduced, and in the 500- to 4000-Hz octave bands, C50 increases when scattering is reduced and decreases when the scattering is increased. Details of steps 4–6 are presented in detail in “Appendix 2”.

With the calibration completed, the initial values are compared to those of the final calibrated GA model. Figure 9 shows T20, EDT, C50, and C80 before and after the calibration compared to the measured values. In the initial iteration, the reverberation parameters (T20 and EDT) were underestimated—especially in the lower octave bands. The clarity parameters (C50 and C80) were overestimated. In the final iteration, the average T20 and EDT were within 1 JND, as was C50, except in the 2000-Hz octave band, and C80, except in the 125 Hz. Finally, the calibrated GA model results are compared to the measurements using the run-to-run variation, established during step 2 of the calibration procedure. The acoustic parameter results are within the average run-to-run variation in the measured value, except for the C50 and C80 in the-2000 Hz octave band.

The main adjustments in the GA model’s surface properties were the adjustment of the plaster surfaces’ absorption coefficients and the raising of the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the limestone and plaster surfaces. Various reasons can explain the difference between the initial and final GA models’ absorption coefficients for the plaster surfaces. For a more extensive discussion on the material properties, see “Appendix 2”.

RIR analysis and audio samples

Having employed the various acoustic parameters related to reverberance and clarity as a function of frequency for the calibration of the GA model, it is useful to examine the resulting RIR with regard to other properties. The first analysis presented involves a spectral analysis of the simulated RIR as compared to the measured RIR. Contrary to the acoustic parameter analysis, some additional processing is required concerning the measured RIR prior to their exploitation as audio material.

It should be noted that the process of preparing a measured RIR for auralization is neither trivial nor neutral. First, the frequency response characteristics of the measurement system have been compensated for by creating an equalization filter. The measurement chain (one microphone only) was installed in an anechoic room (IRCAM, Paris), and the impulse response of the omnidirectional speaker was measured at 5\(^{\circ }\) increments in the horizontal plane. The resulting RIRs were time-windowed to 512 points to remove any reflection artifacts, from which the FFT was calculated, and the mean over all directions of the magnitude determined. A filter was generated to match the inverse of this response using the recursive filter design yulewalk method. Nonlinear frequency weighting followed a bark scale approximation, constraining the filter’s level of detail to follow human hearing sensitivity. The resulting filter was applied to all measured RIRs prior to any spectral analysis.

Subsequently, differences in SNR between frequency bands were compensated (Grillon et al. 1995). The RIR was decomposed into one-third octave band components (spanning 100–16,000 Hz). The noise floor was detected by determining the SNR for each one-third octave band. The signals were then windowed at the point 5 dB above the noise floor, eliminating the trailing noise. The decay rate (reverberation time) was then calculated over the entire window, and this decay rate was used to synthesize the continuation of a noise-free reverberant tail. Since a reliable decay estimate reasonably requires at least 15 dB SNR, one-third octave bands with SNR \(<\)20 dB were discarded (muted in the final RIR). This typically resulted in omitting the lowest two one-third octave bands: 100 and 125 Hz. An equal power cross-fade between the measured and synthesized response was applied over the last 10-dB decay of the measured and the first 10 dB decay of the synthesized response to provide a smooth transition, limiting audible artifacts.

After this procedure, the timbre or coloration of the measured and simulated RIRs can be compared. An example comparison is shown in Fig. 10 for Source2-Receiver24. The spectral differences are examined for the early (0–200 ms) and late (200 ms–3 s) parts of the RIR. There is good agreement for the early part of the response, with mean and SD of the differences over one-third octave bands being \(1.3\pm 2.4\) dB. This difference increases slightly for the later part of the response, to \(2.4\pm 2.1\) dB. Comparison of just the magnitude of the differences results in \(2.0\pm 1.8\) and \(2.9\pm 1.3\) dB for the early and late parts of the RIR, respectively.

Subjective comparisons can be made on auralizations of the resulting RIRs. Using the same responses as in the above example, auralizations were created using an extract of anechoic choral music as the source material for convolution, as it is appropriate to the acoustic function of the room. A short extract of an anechoic choral recording of the St. Olaf Cantorei performing Alleluia was chosen. Details of this recording can be found in Freiheit (2010). The anechoic extract, as well as the auralizations produced by convolving the anechoic signal with both the measured and simulated RIRs is provided in Online Resource 1.

It should be noted that the source directivities employed in the simulated and measured RIR were both omnidirectional, for general consistency, while the actual human singing voice has a different directivity pattern, varying with frequency (Katz and d’Alessandro 2007). Therefore, the manner in which this choir signal excites the room in the auralizations will be slightly different than that of a real choir. However, since this difference is shared by both the measured and simulated auralizations, the comparison is unaffected.

Historical study test case with the calibrated model

According to the third assumption of the study, calibration of the GA model at a sufficient number of discrete points provides confidence in the quality of the model at other positions. As such, the calibrated model can be employed to generate a set of RIRs for use in a virtual reality simulation allowing the user to move around in the space with a reasonable degree of confidence in the validity of the acoustic simulation.

Subsequent modifications can be made to the GA model in an effort to estimate the impact of such modifications, with the premise that the calibrated GA model is a validated reference point. For example, in the context of proposed renovations, these virtual reality simulations could be used to examine PA (public address and alarm) systems, investigating and demonstrating the acoustical implications of modifications to the acoustical properties of the space or the PA system itself through changes in source positions or even speaker type. In the context of historical studies, modifications can be made to the GA model to revert rooms to previous states in their history, such as before important renovations (Katz and Wetherill 2005).

In addition to providing interactive explorations, acoustic parameters can be predicted in these modified calibrated GA models. Historical studies of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés have identified a seventeenth-century plan of the building. Not only has the architecture of the abbey church changed over the centuries, but so have the customs concerning the application of adornments in churches. Therefore, the current acoustical conditions could significantly differ from those in the sixteenth and seventeenth century. This study is part of an attempt to bring the liturgical acoustical properties of that time back to life. The following section presents a case study of the acoustical impact of renovations and changes in material usage in the Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

Former configuration of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés

Figure 11 depicts the former plan of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés. The plan has changed at the fifth bay of the nave where next to the right-side aisle a space was created. Furthermore, the sanctuary, the center of the high altar, and the center of the fifth bay of the nave were fully enclosed by screens, as these were the principal areas in the sixteenth and seventeenth century. A final screen, positioned to separate the sanctuary and choir, was probably acoustically and visually transparent.

Since there is little information about the adornments of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés during the sixteenth and seventeenth century, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris was examined as a reference in order to make an ‘educated guess’ regarding what kind of materials could have been used and where these could have been positioned (Wright 2008). In the Notre Dame Cathedral, screens also enclosed the sanctuary and high altar. The screens, presumably extending halfway up the shaft of the sanctuary’s columns, were covered with draperies. Furthermore, Notre Dame Cathedral was furnished for festivities, especially in the area of the sanctuary, by tapestries. By the early sixteenth century, there was scarcely an area of the high altar and sanctuary that was not covered with some kind of fabric during principal festivities. Moreover, the floor immediately in front of the Notre Dame Cathedral’s altar was covered with rugs. Finally, it is assumed that the painted plaster was already present in the Saint-Germain-des-Prés since this was a conventional finishing for churches of that time.

To acquire information about the absorption coefficients of materials described in the previous paragraph, papers which studied these materials and churches which still apply comparable materials were considered. The sound absorption of the tapestries was adopted from Martelotta and Castiglione (2011), a study concerning seventeenth-century tapestries. The absorption of the rugs was adopted from the database in Vorländer (2008). Additionally, in the cathedral of Seville, banners are positioned at the entrance (Alonso et al. 2014). It was assumed that the draperies in the seventeenth-century configuration of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés could have had the same absorption coefficient. Table 1 shows the adopted absorption coefficients, \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\), and their associated surface area in the GA model.

Acoustical conditions in a historical configuration of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés

The principle performers and auditors in the Saint-Germain-des-Prés during the seventeenth century were monks, who were positioned in the principal areas of the high altar and sanctuary. Therefore, current and historical listening conditions are compared when the source is positioned in these areas and the receivers positioned inside and outside these principal areas.

Figure 12 shows that for both the seventeenth century and current configuration, the mean EDT is shorter and the mean C50 is greater across octave bands in the principal areas than in the other areas. In addition, this difference in acoustics between the two areas was greater during the seventeenth century.

Figure 13 presents a mapping of EDT and C50 values in the 1000-Hz octave band for the calibrated reference GA model and the seventeenth-century liturgical GA model.Footnote 7 The quantified results show, as could be expected with the addition of absorption, that the seventeenth-century configuration had a perceptually shorter mean EDT and a perceptually higher mean C50, an effect which is more prominent in the principal areas. Shorter reverberation times and higher clarity are associated with higher speech intelligibility. It is possible, as a result, that the performance of the liturgy in the choir of Saint-Germain-des-Prés following the modifications of the early modern period changed accordingly. For example, it would have been possible, with this increased clarity, to have performed the standard chant repertory at a higher tempo. The increased clarity of the performance space may have also encouraged the composition of new musical forms inspired by, and adapted to, the changed acoustical environment. Further investigations of the implications of these observations are the focus of ongoing studies with historians.

Conclusion

In virtual reality, the calibration of visualized historical venues is necessary if one desires to have confidence in the result or to construct a scientific tool. Similarly, GA models also need to be calibrated in order to obtain valid auralizations which are the basis of interactive auditory virtual reality. This paper presents a methodical approach to calibrate geometrical acoustics models. The method assumes the existence of physical room acoustical measurements. The measurement results are used as a reference for the simulation. Objective acoustic parameters representing subjective acoustical perceptions are employed. Acceptable tolerances in the calibration are based on the generally accepted JND metric for the various parameters, taking into account run-to-run variations for GA algorithms incorporating stochastic components. Measured and simulated RIRs were analyzed using a common tool in order to minimize the effect of analysis implementation variations.

The proposed calibration method starts with the selection of absorption coefficients for the various materials in the geometrical model from available databases. This range of values for each given material is explored in order to adjust the mean reverberation parameters to within 1 JND of the measured value. Adjustments begin with the materials with the largest surface area in the room. Scattering coefficients are adjusted to bring the clarity parameters to within 1 JND of the measured results. The sensitivity to scattering modifications can be studied by running the simulation with the GA model for two extreme cases of scattering definitions. Subsequently, fine calibration adjustments are performed per position, focusing on surfaces near specific source or receiver positions which exhibit excessive variances relative to measured data. These variances are quantified using the standard deviation of differences between measured reference parameters and those of the simulated data.

It should be noted that the spaces considered in the presented study, the amphitheater and Saint-Germain-des-Prés, are rooms with generally well-distributed absorption and reverberation times which are not strongly dependent on the scattering coefficient. As such, the current calibration method may not be applicable to different situations, such as outdoor theaters or subway terminals. Further evaluations are currently underway to examine the suitability of this procedure in alternate cases, such as theatres.

In conjunction with the presentation and validation of the calibration method, a potential application of this approach was carried out: the reconstruction of the acoustical properties of buildings which have been significantly modified over the years. The abbey of the Saint-Germain-des-Prés in Paris was selected for such a study, comparing the current state of the building to a supposed “seventeenth century liturgical” configuration. From the results of this comparison, it was observed that in the principal areas of use there was a higher speech intelligibility, which is in agreement with its usage of that time. Further exploration of this simulation, and the exploration of the use of other calibrated historical virtual acoustical simulations, is the subject of ongoing work.

The proposed calibration method is based on several assumptions. The principle assumption concerns the acoustic parameters selected as calibration metrics. The use of reverberance and clarity parameters needs to be shown to be sufficient, or additional parameters needs to be included in the procedure. Subjective evaluation of auralizations using measured and simulated responses is required to identify to what degree the two are comparable, and what perceptual attributes remain significantly different. Such a subjective evaluation is currently underway and should provide additional information concerning the limits of this calibration procedure.

Validation of virtual reality acoustical simulations as a scientific tool is the subject of future work. This could include subjective listening tests comparing auralizations based on the virtual GA model to measured data. Additionally, one could examine the impact of the addition of a visual model to the auditory perception of the virtual reality experience.

Appendices

Appendix 1: Details of amphitheater calibration

This section details steps 4–6 of the calibration procedure for the amphitheater. Table 2 shows the absorption coefficients, \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) used in the first iteration, and the associated surface areas which were concluded from the material search as proposed in step 1.

Curve initial in Fig. 14 shows the average T20 and C50 which resulted from the use of the material properties presented in Table 2. Subsequently, the absorption coefficients of the Aluminum (walls) and aluminum (ceiling), the materials most used in the amphitheater, were iteratively adjusted to arrive at [0.168, 0.150, 0.099, 0.072, 0.080, 0.072], bringing EDT and T20 within 1 JND, as depicted by Curve step 4 in Fig. 14.

Curve step 4 in Fig. 14 shows that the mean C50 was \(\Delta\)[\(-0.49\), +0.21, +0.33 +0.32, +0.60, 0.50 dB].Footnote 8 Since Fig. 6 showed that increasing the scattering resulted in a lower clarity, the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the aluminum (walls) was increased to 55 mm, the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the plaster board was increased to 10 mm, the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the concrete (floor and wall) was increased to 20 mm, and the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the concrete (ramp) was increased to 20 mm. To raise the mean C50 in the 125-Hz octave band, the scattering in this octave band of these surfaces was set to 5 %. Furthermore, the edge diffusion of the objects was omitted, and the metal construction was modeled with edge diffusion. Curve step 5 shows that after these adjustments the mean difference between measured and simulated C50 changed to \(\Delta\) [\(-0.33\), +0.06, +0.39, +0.20, +0.50, 0.35 dB] which is an improvement across all octave bands except for 1000 Hz.

At the start of step 6, the SD determined over the positions’ difference between measured and simulated T20 was [0.29, 0.18 s] and EDT was [0.44, 0.25 s]. A decrease in these values means a better estimation of the parameters per position. Therefore, a search was conducted for positional differences. It was found that the receivers on the upper mezzanine (R11–15) overestimated the T20 [125, 250 Hz] with \(\Delta\)[+0.14, +0.02 s], while the receivers on the lower mezzanine underestimated this with \(\Delta\)[0.15, 0.06 s]. Since the receivers on the upper mezzanine were closer to the objects and plaster boards, their absorption coefficients were raised to arrive at, respectively [0.25, 0.12] and [0.17, 0.12], while the absorption of the aluminum (walls) and aluminum (ceiling) was lowered to [0.156, 0.146] to retain the same mean reverberation and clarity. After these adjustments, the receivers on the upper mezzanine overestimated the T20 by \(\Delta\)[+0.11, +0.02 s], while the receivers on the lower mezzanine underestimated the T20 by \(\Delta\)[\(-0.11\), \(-0.03\) s]. This resulted in a lower SD of the T20 [0.25, 0.15 s] and EDT [0.37, 0.25 s] and therefore a better estimation of these parameters per position. Curve step 6 shows the resulting mean T20 and C50.

With the calibrated GA model, the initially chosen material properties are compared to those used in the final model. The difference between originally and finally modeled absorption coefficients of the aluminum panels is because the initial values were adopted from data concerning nonperforated aluminum panels on a 300-mm airspace measured in a reverberation chamber. However, in the amphitheater, insulation material is installed behind the aluminum panels. Therefore, the actual absorption properties of the aluminum panels differ from the initially simulated values. The absorption of the objects is difficult to estimate due to the uncertainty in used material and possible panel absorbing properties due to their hollow interior. Beside the change in absorption coefficients, the scattering coefficients for the concrete, plaster board, and aluminum panels were decreased in the 125-Hz octave band, and those of the aluminum (walls), concrete, and plaster board were increased. As the concrete, plaster board, and aluminum panels are large flat surfaces and consequently the surface size is large in relation to the wavelength, it is justified to adopt a scattering of 5 % in the 125-Hz octave band. Furthermore, raising the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the aluminum (walls) can be justified by the metal construction in front of the wall which makes the wall more diffusing in the higher octave bands than initially assumed, and increasing the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the concrete and plaster board is justified by the objects in front these which makes it more diffusing than originally assumed. Additionally, probably for similar reasons, we note that the general guidelines in the CATT-Acoustic manual recommend that it is better to overestimate scattering coefficients than to underestimate them (Dalenbäck 2011, p. 111) (Table 3).

Appendix 2: Details of Saint-Germain-des-Prés calibration

This section details steps 4–6 of the calibration procedure for the Saint-Germain-des-Prés. Table 4 depicts the absorption coefficients, \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\), and surface area assigned to these materials, in first iteration. Curve initial in Fig. 15 shows the average EDT and C80 of the first iteration.

The average T20 and EDT were brought within 1 JND of the measured value by adjusting the absorption coefficient of the painted plaster to [0.010, 0.019, 0.028, 0.032, 0.038, 0.037], since this material represents the largest surface area and therefore has a principal influence on the acoustic response. Curve initial in Fig. 15 shows the average EDT came within one JND after the absorption coefficient was lowered, concluding step 4.

Figure 8 shows that by increasing the scattering, the clarity parameters in the octave bands 500–4000 Hz became lower and vice versa. Curve step 4 in Fig. 15 shows that at this stage the C50 differed \(\Delta\)[\(-1.35\), 0.25, \(-0.26\), 0.98, 1.60, 0.52] from the measurements. Since the clarity in the higher octave bands needed to decrease, the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) was increased to 300 mm for the columns, to 10 mm for the floor, to 55 mm for the walls, and to 55 mm for the ceiling. Additionally, the absorption coefficients of the painted plaster in octave band 2000 Hz was lowered to 0.035. Furthermore, since Fig. 8 did not give an answer how to raise the C50 in the lower octave bands, iteratively adjusting various parameters resulted in finally adding edge diffusion to the columns and raising the absorption of the painted plaster [125, 250, 500 Hz] to [0.013, 0.022, 0.032]. Curve step 5 in Fig. 15 shows that the combination of these measures resulted in a C50 \(\Delta\)[\(-1.01\), 0.03, \(-0.29\), 0.87, 1.43, 0.43], which better estimated the measurement across all octave bands, except in the 500 Hz where it remained approximately the same.

The main adjustments in the GA model’s surface properties were the adjustment of the plaster surfaces’ absorption coefficient as well as the raising of the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the limestone and plaster surfaces. Various reasons can explain the difference between the initial and final modeled absorption coefficients of the plaster surfaces. In the initial iteration, these values were adopted from the material Concrete block, plastered; in the calibrated model, the absorption coefficient more resembles the material Walls, hard surface average (brick walls, plaster, hard floors) [0.02, 0.02, 0.03, 0.03, 0.04, 0.04] found in Vorländer (2008). Since these are both reasonable choices for the absorption coefficient, it can be stated that these fall within the range found in step 1 of the methodological calibration. There are additional reasons why absorption coefficients can differ from the databases: Materials may have experienced transformations due to aging (Garcia et al. 2014). Additionally, probably because the size of elements high in the Saint-Germain-des-Prés is difficult to gauge during a visual inspection, these were underestimated in the initial iteration. This has influenced the estimation of the \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\) of the plaster wall, limestone, plaster arch, and plaster ceiling, which were underestimated in the initial iteration, explaining the increased \({\mathrm{char}}_{\mathrm{depth}}\). Furthermore, because the plaster column has a small size in relation to the wavelength, the addition of the edge diffusion is justified (Table 5).
